projects.title: BoopIt
projects.sub_title: To play BoopIt , Linkitz  gives an instruction through the speaker and you have to follow the instruction. If you succeed, you get the next instruction. It gives the instructions faster and faster as you play. BoopIt is an advanced level game. It uses more components and there are more parts to the code.

instructions.text: Get the BoopIt code from the Saved Programs menu and load the code to Linkitz.
Then unplug the USB petal from the hub, because you will need three other petals for this game: the motion petal, the speaker, and the microphone.
Attach the motion petal, the speaker, and the microphone to the hub.
Linkitz will count down three flashes, two flashes, one flash and then the game starts.
The instructions are: shake it (shake the Linkitz), dark it (cover the Linkitz with your hand to block the light sensor) and tilt it (tilt the Linkitz in the direction of the lit petal).
If you get through 100 instructions, you win and Linkitz plays a victory pattern. Otherwise Linkitz plays a sad pattern and you have to start from the beginning.

projects.title: Dance pal 1
projects.sub_title: Do you like to dance? Make you Linkitz flash in time with your cool dance moves!

instructions.text: Make a program that flashes when it senses motion.  You only need two blocks for the simplest version!
Need a hint?  Put the Flash block inside the Motion Trigger block

explore.text: Use a list to make Linkitz flash up to 4 colors at once
Use more than one flash block to make Linkitz flash diferent colors in sequence.

projects.title: Firefly Jar
projects.sub_title: An easy-to-make project with your Linkitz. When you are done it will look like you caught fireflies in a mason jar!
extra_parts: Medium-size clear glass jar with a lid
A small piece of string, about 5” long.

instructions.text: Make sure your jar is clean and dry. You don’t want any dust or water getting inside your Linkitz.
Download the program called Fireflies from the Saved Program menu.
sub_text: Take a look at the program. It uses random twice. It makes your Linkitz flash green at random intervals, and it randomly chooses which LEDs to light up.

instructions.text: Load the program to your Linkitz

Tape one end of the string to the top of the jar, and the other end to the stem of your hub. You may have to cut a little bit off the string. You want your Linkitz to hang inside the jar, not touching the bottom.
Carefully screw the lid on the jar.
Take your jar into a darkened room and watch the “fireflies” flash.

explore.text: How can you change the Fireflies program to make your “fireflies” flash more frequently?

projects.title: Hot Potato
projects.sub_title: Pass the Linkitz from person to person. Don’t be left holding Linkitz when the buzzer sounds!
extra_parts: You can also use the Motion petal for more lights, if you don’t have a Speaker petal

instructions.text: Download the program called Hot Potato from the Saved Program menu.
Take a look at the program. You’ll see that it checks to see if a speaker is attached, so it knows if it should make a sound at the end of the game.
The program uses a timer set to a random amount of time, so the players don’t know when the time will run out. It’s different every time you play the game.
Load the program to Linkitz

The Linkitz will start flashing. Pass the Linkitz from person to person. The flashing gets faster and faster until Linkitz glows solid red. Whoever is holding the Linkitz when it goes red is “out” and has to leave the game. Play again until only one person is left. The last one left is the winner.
If you have a speaker attached, the Linkitz will glow red and buzz when the timer is up.

projects.title: Nightlight
projects.sub_title: If you charge your Linkitz for a while before you go to bed, the batteries will last long enough to keep you company all night. Watch your favorite colors glow and change as you fall asleep.
extra_parts: A sheet of letter-size lightweight white printer paper or parchment paper

instructions.text: Measure 4 inches down from the top of the paper on either side and draw a line from one side of the paper to the other. This will be your folding line.
Draw another line from one side of the paper to the other, 1 inch below the folding line. This will be your cutting line.
Cut the paper on the cutting line. We will use the smaller piece*.
Fold the paper on the folding line. This double-layer of paper will be the base of the nightlight.
Roll the paper into a tube, keeping the folded edge on the bottom. Don’t overlap the edges too much! Make sure that the tube fits around your Linkitz.  Then tape the tube to keep it rolled.
Decide on the colors you want your nightlight to glow.

Get program Nightlight-Easy from the Saved program list. This lets you put in two colors that will take turns lighting for 10 seconds each. Drag your favorite colors to the Fade blocks. If you leave the Fade blocks empty, Linkitz will pick two colors to glow and change them every 10 seconds.

explore.text: How would you change Nightlight-Easy to glow in more than two colors?

Check out how the Fade block works. How would you make each color glow for longer than 10 seconds? note: If you use too many colors, or set the glow timer for too long, your batteries might not last for the whole night.
Keep the larger piece to make a paper airplane http://www.origami-instructions.com/paper-airplanes.html

projects.title: Rainbow Flash
projects.sub_title: How far is it to the end of the rainbow? This game counts your movements and displays a rainbow light show when you reach the goal.

instructions.text: Download the Rainbow Flash code from the Saved Program list.
The code has three parts.
The OnStart block sets up a list of rainbow colors, and sets the counter to 0.

The MotionTrigger block adds one to the counter every time it senses motion, and flashes one color. As the number of your movements gets bigger, the color moves to the next color in the rainbow colors list.
The Timing block checks every second to see if the counter has reached the goal (127).  If it has, it flashes the whole rainbow and then resets the counter to zero.
Load the code to Linkitz, and start moving. When you see the rainbow flash, YAY! You did it!

explore.text: Does anyone you know wear a FitBit™ on their wrist? Many grown ups use these to make sure they walk 10,000 steps a day. The biggest number Linkitz can count to is 127. Can you think if a way to get Linkitz to count to higher numbers? hint: Use another counter. What is 127 x 127?

projects.title: Red Light Green Light
projects.sub_title: Have you ever played “Red Light, Green Light”? It’s a classic game and Linkitz makes it even more fun.
extra_parts: You can also use the motion link too

instructions.text: Download the program called Red Light Green Light from the Saved Programs menu.
This program uses random to flash red then green, over and over, for different amounts of time.
Load it to your Linkitz.
To play:
sub_text: To play, one person is chosen to be the traffic cop.
All the players stand on the starting line and the traffic cop stands with her back to the rest of the players.
When the Linkitz flashes green the traffic cop shouts "green light". The other players try to run to the finish line.
When the Linkitz flashes red, the traffic cop shouts "red light," and turns around. The other players have to freeze.
If the traffic cop catches a player moving, she sends them back to the starting line.
The first person to cross the finish line wins, and becomes the new traffic cop.

explore.text: Change the program to flash red or green randomly, instead of always green-red-green-red. If you shout “red light” when everyone is already frozen, sometimes people start to run!

projects.title: Rock Paper Scissors
projects.sub_title: Want to play Rock Paper Scissors but you’re all alone? No problem, Linkitz knows how to play this game! One, two three, GO!

instructions.text: Download the Rock Paper Scissors code from the Saved Programs menu.
To play, Linkitz will flash green three times (counting to three) and then show a pattern of lights.
sub_text: Rock is the smallest hand sign, so if Linkitz chooses rock, it will only light the hub (red lights for rock). If you threw paper, you win because paper covers rock. But if you threw scissors, Linkitz wins, because rock breaks scissors.

Paper is the biggest hand sign so if Linkitz chooses paper, it lights the hub and all three petals (purple lights for paper). If you threw scissors, you win, because scissors cut paper. But if you threw rock, you lose, because paper covers rock.

Scissors hand sign looks like a V, so if Linkitz chooses scissors, it will light up two petals and the hub, making a V shape from lights (sapphire blue for scissors). If you threw rock, you win, because rock breaks scissors. But if you threw paper, you lose, because scissors cut paper.
Did you win? Try again! Linkitz will play 10 times.

projects.title: Simone
projects.sub_title: Simone is a "Follow Me" game.  It tests your memory skill. Play it and see how many moves you can remember!

instructions.text: Download the Simone code from the Saved Programs list, and load the code to Linkitz.
To play Simone, your Linkitz will start by flashing one petal one color. Tilt your Linkitz in the direction of the petal that flashed.
If you do it in time, Linkitz will flash the same petal and then another and wait for you to tilt the Linkitz in the direction of each petal, in order.
On each turn, Linkitz will add another flashing petal and wait for you to tilt the Linkitz in the direction of the flashes.
If you can tilt the pattern of 10 flashes in a row, you win! Linkitz rewards you with a victory pattern!
If you don’t repeat the pattern in time, or make a mistake, you’ll get a sad  pattern and the game will start again.

explore.text: Once you can easily repeat a pattern of 10, change the game to make a longer pattern.

projects.title: Team Spirit
projects.sub_title: Your Linkitz can help you cheer your team on in the Big Game!

instructions.text: Do you know your favorite team’s colors? Here at Linkitz our favorite team’s colors are red and blue.
Write a program that makes your Linkitz flash your team’s colors whenever you clap.
If one of your team’s color’s is black, the LEDs won’t light up at all, so don’t be surprised. You may want to skip using black.
instructions.hint: you need two blocks, Motion Trigger and Flash, plus the color blocks

instructions.text: You can see our code in the Saved Program list. Ours flashes red and blue at the same time.

explore.text: How would you make Linkitz flash first red, then blue? Hint: Check out tutorial 4 if you forgot how to do this.

help.question: My Linkitz looks dead.
solution: If your Linkitz is not flashing any lights, the batteries might be discharged.  After being deeply discharged (when they run out of battery and then are not charged soon after) Linkitz will need to be allowed to charge for an extended period of time (several hours or overnight) before they'll start again.

help.question: My Linkitz is not executing my code.
solution: Make sure that the cable is securely connected to both the USB petal and your computer/laptop, and try uploading again.

Some USB cables are for charging only, and are not USB data cables. If you substituted another cable, this might be causing the problem. A charge-only cable cannot transmit your program to the Linkitz. The cable that came with your Linkitz carries both charge and data.
Your code might have an error that prevents the code from executing. An example of this would be a loop that says While x is true, do, but x is set to 0.

help.question: I get an error when uploading.
solution: My Linkitz is connected but I am getting an error message “Error connecting to Linkitz” when I try to upload code

This can happen when your computer has been idle for a while, especially if it has gone to sleep. Try quitting and then restarting the Linkitz app. If you have written new code, remember to save it before you quit!

help.question: LED petal isn't lighting up.
solution: I’ve programmed my Linkitz to light up but the LED petal is not lighting up.

All the Linkitz components include LEDs. Depending on how your code is written, different LEDs might light up, that are not on the LED petal. Check out this tutorial for an explanation of how to control the LEDs.

help.question: My motion sensor is not responding to motion.
solution: Make sure your program includes a block that gets data from the motion sensor (onMotion or getMotionData).
Sometimes, immediately after being programmed, the Linkitz hub loses track of which petals are connected. Try unplugging all the petals and plugging them in again.

help.question: Help! My Linkitz got wet!
solution: Linkitz contains sensitive electronics. If they were completely immersed, we can’t guarantee what will happen, even after they completely dry out.

questions.question: Is Linkitz waterproof? Is Linkitz water-resistant?
answer: No and no. Keep your Linkitz away from water!

questions.question: Can I track my dog/backpack with Linkitz?
answer: You can’t track them in the sense of watching them move around in real time. With two sets of Linkitz, using the radio and an output petal (LED or speaker), you can get notified when your dog or backpack is outside a certain range, so you can run and get it.

questions.question: How many petals are needed for Linkitz to work?
answer: The hub contains the microprocessor and has it’s own LEDs, so depending on the program you want to run, it might not need any petals.

questions.question: What is the most petals that a Linkitz can hold at the same time?
answer: Linkitz can hold three petals.

questions.question: How long does Linkitz hold a charge?
answer: This depends on what program you are running and how much you are using your Linkitz. If you have three petals attached and are running a program that has all the LEDs on full power all the time, the batteries might run out in just a few hours. In normal usage, the batteries should last a whole day.  Linkitz will let you know that it needs to be plugged in because the LEDs will get dimmer and dimmer and flash less frequently as the batteries use up their power.

questions.question: How do I charge my Linkitz?
answer: Charge your Linkitz using the cable that came in the the box, or any USB-to-microUSB cable. Plug the USB petal (orange) into the hub (yellow). Plug the small end of the USB cable into the USB petal. Plug the large end into a computer or laptop. Your hub will begin to flash to let you know that it is properly connected. It’s OK to have other petals plugged in when charging. They may light up during charging, too.

questions.question: Is it possible to overcharge my Linkitz?
answer: No, it's not possible to overcharge your Linkitz. You can leave it plugged in as long as you want.

questions.question: What happens if the battery drains completely?
answer: The Linkitz hub uses two tiny rechargeable batteries. It’s not good to let rechargeable batteries drain completely. The battery will have a longer lifetime if you keep your Linkitz charged. The batteries will turn off automatically when they're out, but it's not good for the batteries to store a Linkitz that's been run completely dead.

questions.question: How do I change a petal?
answer: Gently pull the petal straight out of the hub to detach it. Gently push a petal into any slot on the hub to attach it.  You can watch a video that shows you how to assemble and take apart Linkitz. [link to make page]

questions.question: Can I attach multiple petals with the same function (for example, 3 speakers)?
answer: Yes. You can attach any number of output petals. For input petals, the hub will only read data from one even if you have two or three attached.

questions.question: Do the wristbands contain latex?
answer: No, the wristbands are latex-free.

questions.question: Can I use my Linkitz without the wristband?
answer: Sure! Some games are easier to play if you hold Linkitz in your hand.

questions.question: Does it hurt the Linkitz to get too hot or too cold?
answer: Linkitz are happiest at the same temperature that you are comfortable in. If Linkitz get too hot or too cold, the batteries might stop operating properly.

questions.question: How can I learn to program my Linkitz?
answer: There are a few ways to learn to program Linkitz.
If you are a complete beginner, we suggest that you start with our tutorials. They introduce the different programming blocks and take you from newbie to Linkitz coder in easy-to-follow steps.

If you have already programmed before, for example, with a language like Scratch, you’ll find Blockly easy to pick up. You can download the code for any of the games that the Linkitz team has written. See how it works, and experiment with making some changes, and see how they affect your Linkitz.
Or, just jump in! Drag some blocks onto the workspace, connect them together, upload the code, and watch your Linkitz to see what happens. Not what you expected? Go back and try again!

questions.question: Is coding with Blockly “real” programming?
answer: Yes! Blocky is a visual programming editor that lets you create real programs by connecting blocks. The Linktz app then translates those pictures into another programming language that our hardware can run.  But when you create your code in Blockly, you are creating the programming logic, such as creating a sequence of actions, or deciding between two options based on some input.

questions.question: I have an idea for a program. Can I send it to you?
answer: We’d love to hear from you. You can reach us using this contact form. If you are under 13 years of age, please ask your parents to contact us, instead. And be sure to let us know if we can share your idea with our other Linkitz friends on our website!

questions.question: Who makes Linkitz?
answer: Linkitz are made by Lyssa and Drew, with help from some friendly designers and engineers.

questions.question: Where are Linkitz made?
answer: Linkitz components are manufactured in Asia and the USA and assembled in San Francisco, California.

questions.question: Can I order replacement parts?
answer: Yes, please contact us for availability here.

stats.title: Most girls become interested in STEM at the age of 11-and-a-half but this starts to wane by the age of 15.
stats.sub_title: Just 42% said they would consider a STEM-related career in the future

stats.title: Girls start believing they aren't goof at math, science and even computers at a young age - but providing fun STEM activities at school and home may spark interest and inspire confidence.
stats.sub_title: A new I-LABS find that, when exposed to a computer-programming activity, 6-year-old girls expressed greater interest in technology and more positive attitudes about their own skills and abilities than girls who didn't try the activity.

stats.title: A 2015 study found that boys are more likely to play with toys that develop spatial intelligence-K'nex, puzzles, Lego bricks-than girls are
stats.sub_title: Marketing can certainly play a role. The girl-oriented product line Lego Friends focuses on playcating rather than construction... Spatial skills are "not only important for math and science but for what we call 'executive function'–higher-level thinking. Being comfortable with certain types of toys may also shape kids' confidence in specific subject."

stats.title: In elementary school about as many girls as boys have positive attitudes toward science. A recent study of fourth graders showed that 66 percent of girls and 68 percent of boys reported liking science.
Research shows that 66 percent of girls between ages 6 and 12 say they're interested in computer science.
stats.sub_title: But around adolescence, interest drops off in a major way–only 32 percent of 13-to-17-year-old girls are interested in computer programs, and only 4 percent of college freshmen are. That's a problem, because by 2020, there will be more than 1.2 million available jobs in tech–and at this rate, women in the U.S. are on track to fill on track to fill 3 percent of them.

stats.title: Young women are not getting enough practical, hands-on experience with STEM subjects.
stats.sub_title: 60% admitted they would feel more confident pursuing a career in STEM fields if they knew men and women were equally employed in those professions.

members.name: Lyssa Neel
members.title: Founder / CEO
members.bio: A computer scientist by training, Lyssa is a passionate about sharing her love for programming. Before co-founding Linkitz, she served as CEO and CTO for several IT start-ups in the United States and Canada. She also co-founded the University of Toronto Early Stage Technology program. Lyssa is a graduate of MIT, where she received SB, SM, and PhD degress from the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science.

members.name: Drew Macrae
members.title: Founder / CTO
members.bio: Drea is a lifelong engineer: he has been taking things apart since he was five years old, and putting them back together since he was seven (sorry, Dad!). Before co-founding Linkitz, Drew was a Silicon Architecture Engineer at Intel, and previously worked at Tesla Motors and Mentor Media. Drew has a Bachelor's degree in Engineering from Harvey Mudd College. An all aorund player, Drew leads both the mechanical and electrical engineering effort at Linkitz.

members.name: Chris Wallace
members.title: Founder
members.bio: Chris holds a Doctorate in Classics from the University of Toronto. His research has been published around the globe and translated into four languages. He has been teaching for more than a decade and loves helping kids realize how much they already know. Chris makes sure that Linkitz will delight kids, satisfy parents and support teachers.

members.name: Elli Chemel
members.title: Product Advisor
members.bio: Ellis is the complete Product Expert. With his background in design, a former buyer at Target, and a Global Brand Manager at Spin Master Ltd., he brings expertise from "all sides of the house".

philosophy: Social interaction and cooperative play are the objectives behind the design and development of Linkitz. As a technology toy, this sets Linkitz apart. We aren’t a toy that you just play with alone. We’re a toy that responds to you and your friends: adding color to a game of tag by lighting up when you’re chasing someone, turning a game of Miss Mary Mack or Slide into a rave with lights that keep time to your clapping, or sensing when you’re near a friend (who is also wearing Linkitz) and lighting up to celebrate your friendship. Linkitz facilitates amazing experiences where a girls’ imagination is the only limit.

Our team has never thought of technology as just sitting down and building something for its own sake -- to us it has always been about finding ways to solve problems and make things work better. That’s the side of technology that Linkitz invites kids to explore and enjoy. It’s a toy that shows them how much there is to love about making things, and lets them share that love with their friends.
We believe that Linkitz’s combination of hardware, code, design and wearable possibilities teaches STEM through freedom of play and exploration.
